Suskind names new committee
to investigate pre-med problems
A committee has been formed
to review and evaluate the
Pre-medical program at Hopkins
and make recommendations for
an over-all upgrading of the
Program, Dean of Academic
Programs Sigmund Suskind has
announced.
The formation of this group is
part of a University effort to
examine the pre-med program
and direct more attention to the
40 percent of the undergraduate
student body working toward a
medical degree.
The Committee on the
Pre-Medical Program is composed
of members of both the Arts and
Sciences and Medical School
faculties. The committee is
serving as a subcommittee of the
Undergraduate Studies
Committee chaired by Suskind.
According to the Dean, the
committee will investigate and
make recommendations on
curriculum, instruction facilities
and advising and counseling in
the pre-med program.
Suskind placed great emphasis

on the cooperation between
Homewood and the Medical
School in the committee.
"We have been trying to
formalize contacts between Arts
and Sciences and the Med School
in pre-med education for a long
time, and the medical faculty is
now showing its willingness to
work with us in this area,"
remarked Suskind.
"In the past," noted Suskind,
"for all practical purposes, the
Medical School didn't seem to
know that pre-med
undergraduates on the
Homewood campus existed."
"By working with people
down at the Med School we will
be able to see if we are training
our pre-meds properly," Suskind
stressed.
Complaint
Suskind listed among the
objectives to be studied the
adaptation of pre-med lab
courses to make them more
applicable to medicine. A
common complaint of students
in the program is that the lab

courses do not seem properly
oriented toward medicine.
Attention
The establishment of the
committee follows
recommendations in the Blue
Ribbon Panel's final report on
undergraduate education released
last spring which called for
increased attention for the
pre-medical program.

Gerhard K. Friesen. of the
German Department appreciates

advanced course in conversation
and composition as well as
graduate courses. His special field

novel.

particular interest in what he
terms "literary sociology." He
describes this as "The study of
some of the effects of literary
Works and their sociological
implications.'
His training in comparative
literature has also brought him
into extensive contact with
French and Spanish culture.
A Canadian, Dr. Friesen
Professes to be a "student of
national characteristics." He is
Particularly fascinated with the
origin and historical development
of changing national images.

Germans no longer have the
r eputation that they did in

d runkards.
In order to illustrate

concepts, he likes to refer to a
novel called "Somnium," written
in Latin by the German scientist
Kepler.
It concerns the project of a
-tr1P to the moon. The crew of
the spaceship
were to be
Spaniards, since in those
days
S paniards were generally
considered to
be the most stoic,
hardY, and reliable of peoples.
Living in Germany until he
Was 17,
Dr. Friesen experienced

"a rigorous exposure to sports,"
especially soccer. He still enjoys
track and field, and other
spectator sports.
Other interest that absorb

theatre and music, as well as
history in general. He also likes

At Hopkins he is the
coordinator of the German

advising. As concerns teaching,

feels, rather, that "a professor

interchange, and rapport," in his
classes.

Jays open season tomorrow at Muhlenberg
By NILS BRUBAKER
The Blue Jay footballers open
the 1972 season tomorrow at
Allentown, Pennsylvania against
Muhlentrerg, with a good chance
to take the first step on the way
to an MAC Southern Division
title.
With 19 returning lettermen in
the starting line-up, and a
four-game winning streak at the
finish of last year's season,
Hopkins should have the
necessary experience and
momentum to improve upon its
6-3 record of last fall.
The key player on the team
this year is, not surprisingly,
quarterback Jack Thomas.
According to Head Coach Dennis
Cox, Thomas is going into this
season with "more confidence,
more poise, and more polish"
than he had last season. Under
his leadership, the offense was
the highest scoring in the division
last season, and there is no reason
why the Jays cannot repeat this
year.
To throw to, Thomas will have
veteran wide receiver Grant
Shevchik and last year's leading
receiver, tight end Rick
Kowalchuk, whom Cox sees as
playing another important role
this year.
To replace graduated ground
leader Butch Robey at halfback,
Hopkins has come up with senior
Tim Doyle, a transfer student
from Clemson, who appears
perfectly, capable of filling
Robey's shoes. Rounding out the
offensive backfield for this
Saturday will be co-captain Jim
Ferguson at fullback and Hal
Altman at right halfback, with
capable Pat Neary in reserve.
The offensive line was
described by Cox as "strong
down the middle." High praise
was awarded to center Sam
Palmisano, whom Cox has called
the best .center he has coached
since Wayne Mulligan, presently
of the St. Louis Cardinals.

Plaudits also went to left guard
Joe Ouslander, who has "worked
so hard, and looked so good."
Coach Cox thinks Joe could be a
definite All-Conference selection
by the end of the season.
The other offensive linemen
are guard Jim Adams,and tackles
Barry Van Orman and Mike
Riley. The Blue Jay defense
features an excellent secondary
of Harry Stringer, Les Mathews
("improved 200% last year"),
and Billy Nolan, all returning as a
unit from last year.
Leading the linebacking squad
are Gunter Glocker and Jim
Moran, who watch the middle,
while Craig Stevens and Richard
Hagerty watch the outside, but
play on the line, inside the ends,
in Coach Cox's 6-2-3 alignment.
In the front four, the Jays will
field steady Bruce Jackson and
wuick Rick Kuehn at ends. Mike
O'Brien and Keith Krantz at
tackles will be bearing the brunt
of opposition running attacks.
While the Jays will be fielding
basically the same personnel as
last year, with more experience,
Muhlenberg will be showing
Hopkins a different face.
They still have wide receiver
George Wheeler, who hauled
down a last-second 61 -yard pass
in last year's game to set up the
winning touchdown. But gone is
the man who threw that pass,
quarterback Ed DiYanni, last
year's MAC total offense leader.
With his passing arm missing,
Muhlenberg will be expected to
run more often this year.
The Allentown team's
strength, though, is in its defense.
Like Hopkins, their defensive
secondary is returning intact and
in good shape. They also feature
two excellent linebackers, Easen
and Schneider.
Nevertheless, for Coach Cox,
the key to tomorrow afternoon's
game lies in Hopkins offensive
power. He hopes to establish at
least one good running play early

in the game which Muhlenberg
has to stop, and then exploit
what weaknesses they leave open
when they try to compensate.
Here, the positions to watch are
the Jays' offensive tackles, to see
how well they can immobilize
their opponents and make
off-tackle and outside plays
work.
Defensively, the Blue Jays will
have to stop Muhlenberg's
running game. Cox sees the left
side of the defensive line (Kuehn,
Stevens, O'Brien) as playing the
key role.
In summing up the team's
chances, the coach, not wanting
to appear over-confident, was
hesitant to predict victory. And
rightfully so. Muhlenberg has
only played once in scrimmage
and it is too difficult to evaluate
them just yet. Hopkins has good
personnel, but by no means do
the Jays have a big edge in that
department.

embarrassing signs that some of the artists
had real difficulty dealing with
perspective. Another disappointment is

the procession of vases and bowls of fruit

no ordinary museum.
